summary.text:
National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 - Authorizes appropriations for the Department of Defense (DOD) for FY 2004 for: (1) armed forces procurement, including aircraft, missiles, weapons and tracked combat vehicles, ammunition, shipbuilding and conversion, the defense health program, and chemical agents and munitions destruction; (2) research, development, test and evaluation; (3) operation and maintenance, including defense working capital funds and the Armed Forces Retirement Home; and (4) active and reserve military personnel, including authorized end strengths.

Increases as of January 1, 2004, the rates of military basic pay. Extends certain bonus and special and incentive pay authorities. Authorizes an incentive bonus for conversion to undermanned military occupational specialties.

Sets forth provisions or requirements concerning: (1) active and reserve military personnel policy; (2) military education and training; (3) military health care; (4) acquisition policy and management, including Buy American requirements and the temporary assignment to DOD of certain non-Government personnel; (5) DOD organization and management; (6) space activities, including the provision of space surveillance network services to U.S. and non-U.S. Government entities; (7) DOD civilian personnel policy; (8) matters relating to other nations, including the recognition of superior noncombat achievements by friendly foreign forces or foreign nationals; (9) homeland security, including the sale of chemical and biological defense articles and services to State and local governments; and (10) military construction and military family housing.

National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2004 - Division A: Department of Defense Authorizations - Title I: Procurement - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 101) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for the Army, Navy and Marine Corps, and Air Force for aircraft, missiles, weapons and tracked combat vehicles, ammunition, shipbuilding and conversion, and other procurement.

(Sec. 104) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for defense-wide procurement.

Subtitle B: Army Programs - (Sec. 111) Limits the obligation of FY 2004 funds for the Army's Stryker vehicle program until: (1) the Secretary of the Army has submitted a report to the Deputy Secretary of Defense on modifications of the equipment and configuration of Stryker brigades; (2) the Secretary of Defense (Secretary) has submitted such report to the congressional defense and appropriations committees, along with a certification concerning the fielding of a fourth Stryker brigade as planned by the Army; and (3) 30 days have elapsed since those committees received such report and certification.

(Sec. 112) Directs the Secretary of the Army to configure the fourth Stryker brigade combat team so that it provides a combat capability and sustainability well beyond that provided by any of the first three teams. Provides funding. Requires a report from such Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees concerning the newly configured team.

Subtitle C: Navy Programs - (Sec. 121) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to enter into a multiyear procurement contract, beginning with: (1) the FY 2004 program year, for tactical Tomahawk cruise missiles, as well as seven Virginia-class submarines; and (2) the FY 2005 program year, for up to 234 aircraft in the F/A-18E, F/A-18F, and EA-18G configurations. Requires 30 days' prior notification of the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the submarines procurement.

(Sec. 124) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy, beginning with the FY 2004 program year, to enter into multiyear procurement contracts for: (1) four E-2C and four TE-2C aircraft; and (2) 16 engines for such aircraft.

(Sec. 125) Provides that if after May 7, 2003, there is enacted an Act making supplemental appropriations for the Department of Defense (DOD) for FY 2003 that includes an appropriation for the procurement of Tomahawk cruise missiles: (1) the amount provided for weapons procurement for the Navy under this Act shall be reduced; and (2) the amount provided for shipbuilding and conversion shall be increased by the same amount, and used for the advanced procurement of long-lead items for one LPD-17 class vessel.

Subtitle D: Air Force Programs - (Sec. 131) Establishes the Air Force Air Refueling Transfer Account, and authorizes appropriations to the Account. Provides authorized uses of Account funds. Authorizes the Secretary of the Air Force to transfer Account funds for necessary purposes after 30 days' prior notification of the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 132) Amends the Bob Stump National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2003 (Stump Act) to increase from 40 to 42 the procurement authority for C-130J aircraft.

(Sec. 133) Prohibits the Secretary of the Air Force from retiring C-5A aircraft to a number below 112 until: (1) the Air Force has modified such aircraft to a specified configuration; and (2) the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation has conducted an evaluation of the aircraft and provides an operational assessment to the Secretary and the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 134) Limits FY 2004 funding availability for the procurement of F/A-22 aircraft until the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics makes a certification to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the operational test and evaluation of the aircraft. Authorizes the Secretary to waive the certification requirement after notification to such committees.

Title II: Research, Development, Test, and Evaluation - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 201) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for the armed forces for research, development, test, and evaluation (RDT&E). Earmarks specified amounts for the Defense Science and Technology Program.

(Sec. 203) Increases the amount authorized for RDT&E under this Act, to be used for: (1) computer-assisted medical diagnostic technology; (2) advanced technology development for lightweight cartridge cases for ammunition; (3) aviation-shipboard information technology; (4) the AutoREAD system for aircraft launch and recovery; (5) development and demonstration of the SPIKE urban warfare system; (6) research in hydrographic sciences; (7) shipboard electronic warfare improvements; (8) aerospace sensors; (9) elemental detector technology appraisal; and (10) an antidote for mustard gas.

Subtitle B: Program Requirements, Restrictions, and Limitations - (Sec. 211) Directs the Secretary to establish and carry out a collaborative program for evaluation and demonstration of advanced technologies and concepts for advanced gun systems that use electromagnetic propulsion for direct and indirect fire applications. Requires: (1) the Secretaries of the Army and Navy to carry out separate programs under such evaluation and demonstration; and (2) a joint implementation report from such Secretaries and the Director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 212) Authorizes the Secretary, in selecting a Director for the Department of Defense Test Resources Management Center, to choose from senior DOD civilian officials and employees with substantial experience in the field of test and evaluation. (Currently, the Secretary must select for such position only from among active-duty commissioned officers.)

(Sec. 213) Directs the Secretary to designate a single joint program office within DOD for management of the Joint Tactical Radio System development program.

(Sec. 214) Prohibits the obligation of any RDT&E funds under this Act for the development and demonstration of systems for the Future Combat Systems program until 30 days after the Secretary of the Army reports to the defense and appropriations committees on such program. Requires separate program elements under such program for fiscal years beginning with 2004.

(Sec. 215) Directs the Secretary to: (1) assess promising technologies for the enhanced U.S. production of titanium; and (2) select the most viable of such technologies for research, development, and production. Provides funding from RDT&E funds.

(Sec. 216) Amends the Stump Act to extend for FY 2004 a reporting requirement with respect to the RAH-66 Comanche aircraft program.

(Sec. 217) Directs the Secretary to provide for the performance of eight independent studies on alternative future fleet platform architectures for the Navy. Requires: (1) study results to be forwarded to the defense and appropriations committees; and (2) each study to present one or two possible architectures. Earmarks RDT&E funds for such studies.

Subtitle C: Ballistic Missile Defense - (Sec. 221) Amends Federal provisions concerning program elements of ballistic missile defense programs to: (1) repeal current program elements; and (2) authorize the President to specify such elements.

Title III: Operation and Maintenance - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 301) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for operation and maintenance (O&M) for the armed forces and specified activities and agencies of DOD.

(Sec. 302) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for: (1) working capital funds; (2) the defense health program; (3) chemical agents and munitions destruction, defense; (4) defense drug interdiction and counter-drug activities; (5) the Defense Inspector General; and (6) an initiative for accurately tracing portable, sensitive items exported beyond U.S. borders.

(Sec. 305) Reduces Air Force O&M funds by $135.5 million.

Subtitle B: Environmental Provisions - (Sec. 311) Amends the Sikes Act to extend its authorization of appropriations through FY 2008. Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary take all necessary steps to ensure full implementation of the provisions of such Act, including the implementation of integrated natural resources management plans on lands upon and surrounding military installations. Requires, in the case of such a plan for any military installation on Guam during FY 2004 through 2008, the management, control, and eradication of invasive species not native to the ecosystem of that military installation the introduction of which cause or may cause harm to military readiness, the environment, the economy, or human health or safety.

(Sec. 312) Authorizes the Secretary with respect to a defense agency, or the Secretary of a military department, when engaged in an authorized activity that may or will result in the destruction of or adverse impact to a wetland, to make payments to a wetland mitigation banking program or approved mitigation sponsor for the remediation of such destruction or adverse impact.

(Sec. 313) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to include environmental protection equipment within salvage facilities provided for public and private vessels. Allows claims for salvage services to include claims for environmental protection services.

(Sec. 314) Includes within the Secretary's authority to transport humanitarian relief supplies the authority to transport supplies used to respond to or mitigate the effects of environmental emergencies.

(Sec. 315) Requires the Secretary to amend regulations establishing restoration advisory boards to require board meetings to be held at a reasonable time and manner and be open to the public, and for the public to be given timely notice of such meetings. Makes the Federal Advisory Committee Act inapplicable to such boards.

(Sec. 316) Directs the Secretary to conduct a study of the impacts of the following activities at military installations and operational ranges: (1) civilian community encroachment on such installations and ranges and their buffer areas; (2) DOD compliance with State implementation plans for air quality under the Clean Air Act; and (3) DOD compliance with the Solid Waste Disposal Act and the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense committees on study results.

(Sec. 317) Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to prohibit the Secretary of the Interior from designating as critical habitat any lands or other areas owned or controlled by DOD, or designated for its use, that are subject to an integrated natural resources management plan prepared under the Sikes Act, if such Secretary determines that the plan addresses special management considerations or protection requirements of the Endangered Species Act. Requires such Secretary to consider the impact on national security when considering the designation of a critical habitat.

(Sec. 318) Amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to add the definition of "harassment" with respect to a military readiness activity. Authorizes the Secretary to exempt any action or category of actions undertaken by DOD or its components from compliance with any requirement of such Act if the Secretary determines that the exemption is necessary for national defense. Allows the incidental takings of marine mammals while engaged in a military readiness activity, without the publication of notice of such takings required under such Act.

(Sec. 319) Limits Army responsibility for water consumption impacts related to Fort Huachuca, Arizona, to responsibility for consumption occurring specifically on such installation and not outside thereof.

(Sec. 320) Authorizes the use of Army O&M funds to construct wetlands crossings at the Camp Shelby Combined Arms Maneuver Area, Mississippi.

Subtitle C: Workplace and Depot Issues - (Sec. 321) Excludes all funds available to the military departments and defense agencies for depot-level maintenance and repair workloads (currently, only those so available during FY 2003 through 2006) from percentage limitations on the contracting-out of such workloads for private performance.

(Sec. 322) Directs the Secretary to establish a pilot program under which the Secretary of each military department shall administer, or continue the implementation of, high-performing organizations at military installations through the conduct of a Business Process Reengineering Initiative. Describes eligible organizations. Limits program participation to 15 military installations. Exempts organizations designated under the Initiative as high-performing from any Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Circular A-76 competition or other public-private competition involving any function studied under the Initiative. Requires the Secretaries to conduct annual performance reviews of such organizations.

(Sec. 323) Prohibits studies or competition from being conducted under the policies and procedures contained in any revisions to the above Circular, as in effect on May 1, 2003, for possible contracting-out of work being performed by DOD employees until 45 days after the Secretary reports to Congress on the impacts and effects of such revisions.

(Sec. 324) Requires the Secretary of the Navy to establish a demonstration project during FY 2004 through 2006 under which three naval aviation depots may promote by one grade level workers certified at the journey level to perform multiple trades. Prohibits more than 15 percent of the wage grade journeymen at a project location from being selected to participate. Requires: (1) the Secretary to report to Congress on project results; and (2) the Comptroller General (CG) to evaluate the report and submit evaluation results to Congress.

Subtitle D: Information Technology - (Sec. 331) Directs the Chief Information Officer of DOD and of each military department to: (1) encourage the use of performance- and results-based management with respect to information technology and national security systems; (2) evaluate the performance and results of investments made in information technology; (3) establish capital planning processes for selecting, managing, and evaluating the results of all major investments in information systems; (4) make recommendations on the use of information technology in support of necessary missions; and (5) ensure adequate information security policies, procedures, and practices. Requires the Secretary to ensure that such activities are also carried out with respect to defense agencies and field activities.

Subtitle E: Other Matters - (Sec. 341) Requires the Secretary to maintain liaison with industry advisory groups to coordinate the development of the defense supply catalog and the standardization program with the best practices of industry and to obtain the fullest practicable cooperation and participation of industry in developing the catalog and standardization program. Repeals a requirement of biennial reports to Congress on the coordination of equipment standardization with NATO members.

(Sec. 342) Directs the Secretary to authorize travel on Government aircraft on a space-available basis for dependents of members assigned to duty at an overseas location for in excess of one year to the same extent as such travel is authorized for dependents of members assigned to that duty location in a permanent change of station status. Considers Alaska and Hawaii an overseas location for purposes of such authority.

(Sec. 343) Prohibits the Secretary from disestablishing, discontinuing, or transferring the weather reconnaissance mission of the Air Force Reserve unless the Secretary determines that another organization or entity can demonstrate that it has the capability to perform the same mission with the same capability.

(Sec. 344) Authorizes the Secretary to transfer to a firefighting or health agency in a State (currently, State and local law enforcement and firefighting agencies) any excess personal property (currently, only specified excess equipment) that the Secretary determines is suitable for use in providing fire and emergency medical services (currently, law enforcement and firefighting services) or for responding to health or environmental emergencies, including communication and monitoring equipment.

(Sec. 345) Requires the Secretary to provide for an independent epidemiological study of exposure to perchlorate in drinking water. Requires the Federal entity conducting the study to report to the Secretary on study results. Directs the Secretary to provide for an independent review of the effects of perchlorate on the human endocrine system, and requires that entity to report to the Secretary on review results.

(Sec. 346) Mandates that public works, utility, and other municipal services needed for the operation of any DOD asset in Monterey County, California, be purchased from government agencies located in that County.

Title IV: Military Personnel Authorizations - Subtitle A: Active Forces - (Sec. 401) Sets forth authorized end strengths for active-duty forces as of the end of FY 2004.

(Sec. 402) Increases effective on October 1, 2003, the permanent active-duty end strength minimum levels.

Subtitle B: Reserve Forces - (Sec. 411) Sets forth the authorized end strengths as of the end of FY 2004 for members of the Selected Reserve and reserve personnel on active duty in support of the reserves.

(Sec. 413) Sets forth the minimum end strength for FY 2004 for Army and Air Force dual status military technicians.

(Sec. 414) Places specified FY 2004 limits on the number of non-dual status technicians authorized to be employed by the Army and Air National Guard.

(Sec. 415) Increases effective October 1, 2007, the permanent limitation on the number of non-dual status technicians authorized to be employed by the Army and Air Force Reserve.

Subtitle C: Authorizations of Appropriations - (Sec. 421) Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for: (1) military personnel; and (2) the Armed Forces Retirement Home.

Title V: Military Personnel Policy - Subtitle A: General and Flag Officer Matters - (Sec. 501) Allows for the selection of the Chief of Naval Operations and Commandant of the Marine Corps from among all Navy flag officers and all general officers of the Marine Corps, respectively. (Currently, such selection must be from active-duty list officers of certain grades.)

Subtitle B: Other Officer Personnel Policy Matters - (Sec. 511) Repeals a provision authorizing the transfer of regular Navy officers between the Navy staff corps and the line of the Navy.

(Sec. 512) Allows health professions officers who have failed of selection for promotion to be retained on active duty until completion of the active duty service for which the officer is obligated, unless the Secretary concerned determines that the completion of such service is not in the best interests of that military department.

(Sec. 513) Allows commissioned officers in grades below lieutenant colonel or commander to be voluntary retired upon serving satisfactorily in that grade for not less than six months. Requires officers in grades above major or lieutenant commander and below brigadier general or rear admiral (lower half) to serve satisfactorily in that grade for three years in order to be so retired, except that such period may be reduced to not less than two years. Requires active duty of not less than one year for eligibility for voluntary retirement for officers in grades above colonel or captain. Allows officers in grades above major general or rear admiral to be voluntarily retired if that officer satisfactorily serves on active duty in that grade for not less than one year. Repeals a requirement requiring advance notification to the defense committees prior to exercising the authority to reduce the three-year time-in-grade requirement to two years.

(Sec. 514) Repeals the requirement that the officer holding the position of defense attache to the U.S. embassy in France hold at least the grade of brigadier general or rear admiral (lower half).

Subtitle C: Reserve Component Matters - (Sec. 521) Repeals the requirement of: (1) selection board participation in the determination whether to continue officers on the reserve active-status list; (2) approval of such continuation by the Secretary concerned; and (3) a continuation board to meet for such purposes.

(Sec. 522) Authorizes a reserve officer who has been ordered to or is serving on active duty in support of a contingency operation to be considered for promotion by a vacancy promotion board for up to two years after the officer begins such duty.

(Sec. 523) Authorizes the Secretary (current law) or the Secretary of Homeland Security (currently, Secretary of Transportation) with respect to the Coast Guard when it is not operating as a service in the Navy, to make exceptions to annual Ready Reserve training requirements.

(Sec. 524) Provides limited authority (currently, none) for the Secretary concerned to delegate the authority to place certain retired members in the Ready Reserve.

(Sec. 525) Includes enlisted personnel within the authority of the Secretary concerned to pay expenses of Army and Air Staff personnel, and National Guard Bureau personnel, attending the national conventions of certain military associations.

Subtitle D: Military Education and Training - (Sec. 531) Authorizes the President of the Marine Corps University to confer the degree of operational studies upon graduates of the Command and Staff College's School of Advanced Warfighting.

(Sec. 532) Includes room and board expenses within financial assistance authorized for cadets and midshipmen receiving Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC) scholarships, as well as for specially selected members of the Army Reserve and Army National Guard enrolled in advanced courses under ROTC programs.

(Sec. 533) Increases from ten to 17 the number of scholarships authorized to be awarded annually at each military junior college under the Army Reserve ROTC scholarship program.

(Sec. 534) Includes any accrued interest within amounts authorized to be repaid under the Selected Reserve critical specialties educational loan repayment program.

(Sec. 535) Entitles a non-scholarship member of the Selected Reserve Officers' Training Corps to a monthly subsistence allowance for up to 20 months. Allows a member of the Senior ROTC who has completed the first year of an ROTC course and who is not eligible for advanced training and who is not an appointed cadet or midshipman to: (1) contract to serve for the period required by the program; and (2) agree to accept an appointment, if offered, as a commissioned officer and to serve for the period prescribed by the Secretary.

(Sec. 536) Increases from two to three the annual number of cadets authorized to be appointed to each of the military service academies from Guam, the Virgin Islands, and American Samoa.

(Sec. 537) Provides that when a formal report by a DOD Inspector General concerning the circumstances of a separation of a cadet or midshipman from a service academy contains a specific finding that such person received administrative or punitive action, or resigned in lieu of such action, as a result of a reprisal or threat of reprisal, then the Secretary concerned may use such report as the sole basis for readmission of the former cadet or midshipman to the respective academy. Requires each Secretary to prescribe readmission regulations with the goal of readmitting such cadet or midshipman with no loss of academic or military status previously held.

(Sec. 538) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to permit enlisted members of any of the armed forces to receive instruction at the Naval Postgraduate School for: (1) executive level seminars; or (2) the information security scholarship program. Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to prescribe exceptions to the requirement of reimbursement by such students for instruction costs.

(Sec. 539) Directs the Secretary to establish a DOD task force to examine matters relating to sexual harassment and violence at the United States Military Academy and United States Naval Academy. Requires the task force to report to the: (1) Secretary recommending ways by which DOD and the service academies may more effectively address such matters; and (2) Secretary and the Secretaries of the Army and Navy on activities of the task force and such academies to respond to sexual harassment and violence at the academies. Requires the Secretary to report to the defense committees on: (1) an evaluation of the above reports; and (2) the Secretary's assessment of the effectiveness of corrective actions being taken at the United States Air Force Academy as a result of various investigations undertaken there with respect to matters involving sexual assault and harassment. Terminates the task force 90 days after submission of its final report.

Subtitle E: Administrative Matters - (Sec. 541) Requires deployment of military personnel to be managed to ensure that a member is not deployed, or continued in deployment, on any day in which the total number of days deployed out of the preceding 730 days would exceed the high-deployment threshold of 400 days or a lower number as prescribed by the Secretary. Provides an exception to such deployment limits when approved by the Secretary. Directs the Secretary concerned to pay a monthly high-deployment allowance for: (1) a member who has been deployed in excess of the high-deployment threshold or for 191 or more consecutive days; and (2) a reserve member on active duty under a call or order to active duty for a period of more than 30 days which is the second such call or order for that member in support of the same contingency operation. Prohibits the monthly allowance from exceeding $1,000. Allows the Secretary concerned to exclude members serving in specified duty assignments from eligibility for the high-deployment allowance, with the approval of the Secretary of Defense. Requires current deployment reporting requirements to include information with respect to members receiving the high-deployment allowance.

(Sec. 542) Increases from 60 to 120 days the amount of annual leave authorized to be accumulated by high-deployment members. Requires the excess leave to be used within three years after termination of the high-deployment period.

(Sec. 543) Standardizes the terminology of time-in-service requirements for voluntary retirement from the Navy and Marine Corps with that used for such requirements with respect to the Army and Air Force.

(Sec. 545) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1996 to provide as a standard for the awarding of the Purple Heart to members held as prisoners of war before April 25, 1962, whether such person was wounded while in captivity or was subject to deprivation of food, medical treatment, and other forms of mistreatment. Requires the Secretary concerned to inform the former prisoner that historical information about the prison camp and other appropriate circumstances may be used and that the former prisoner may submit such information. Directs such Secretary to take into account the length of time that the award applicant was held in captivity to help determine whether the former prisoner was likely to have been wounded, starved, or denied medical treatment.

(Sec. 546) States that restrictions on civilian employment for reserve and retired regular officers shall not apply to the functions of a civil office held by election.

(Sec. 547) Makes the requisite blood alcohol content under the Uniform Code of Military Justice equal to or in excess of (currently, in excess of) the requisite blood alcohol content adopted by the State in which the offense occurs.

(Sec. 548) Prohibits the Secretary from publicly disclosing the name or any other personally identifying information of any member who while on active duty or performing inactive duty training is killed or injured, whose duty status becomes unknown, or who is otherwise considered to be a casualty until 24 hours has elapsed since notification of the next-of-kin of such member.

Subtitle F: Benefits - (Sec. 551) Makes eligible for the Federal Long-Term Care Insurance Program any former Federal employee who has met all other Federal retirement qualifications but has not yet reached the minimum requisite age, including reservists transferred to the Retired Reserve who are under 60 years of age.

(Sec. 552) Removes: (1) the requirement that a member must have died in a military medical facility within the United States in order to be eligible for the transportation of remains for burial; and (2) the prohibition against transportation of such remains to a place outside the United States.

(Sec. 553) Amends the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978 to make eligible for tuition-free education under such Act the dependents of reserve members who: (1) are ordered to active duty; (2) were so ordered from a location inside the United States (other than Alaska or Hawaii); and (3) are serving outside the United States or in Alaska or Hawaii on a tour of duty that has been extended to a period in excess of one year.

Subtitle G: Other Matters - (Sec. 561) Sets forth exemplary conduct requirements to be applicable to all commanding officers and DOD civilians in authority positions, including the safeguarding of the morale, physical well-being, and general welfare of all under their command or charge. Repeals exemplary conduct requirements applicable to commanding officers within each military department.

(Sec. 562) Directs the Secretary to: (1) implement and sustain programs to celebrate the contributions and sacrifices of the American military family; (2) focus such celebrations during a specific period of each year; and (3) seek the assistance and support of appropriate civilian organizations, associations, and other entities in carrying out such celebrations.

(Sec. 563) Earmarks FY 2004 DOD O&M funds for assistance to local educational agencies. Directs the Secretary to notify each agency of its eligibility for such assistance.

(Sec. 564) Authorizes the Secretary of a military department to provide support services to chaplain-led programs to assist active-duty military personnel and their immediate family members and reserve active-status personnel and their immediate family members in building and maintaining a strong family structure.

(Sec. 565) Establishes the Department of Veterans Affairs-Department of Defense Joint Executive Committee to recommend to the Secretaries of such departments the strategic direction for joint coordination and sharing efforts between and within such departments. Requires an annual report from the Committee to the Secretaries and Congress.

(Sec. 566) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to: (1) ensure that no reductions are made in the active and reserve force structure of the Navy and Marine Corps for fixed- and rotary-wing aircraft until 90 days after such Secretary has submitted to the defense committees a detailed report on the changes to the active and reserve Navy aviation force structure that are proposed for FY 2004 through 2009; and (2) submit to such committees a concept of operations for increasing the integration and use of Naval Reserve surface, aviation, and other units and personnel with active forces in carrying out operational missions during 2004 through 2009.

(Sec. 567) Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize impact aid for heavily impacted local educational agencies that lost eligibility for such assistance due to the privatization of military housing in that area.

(Sec. 568) Requires the Secretary to: (1) commence a new investigation into the death of Colonel James S. Sabow, United States Marine Corps, who died on January 22, 1991, at the Marine Corps Air Station, El Toro, California, with the principal investigative focus being the determination of the cause of death; and (2) report findings to the defense committees.

Subtitle H: Domestic Violence - (Sec. 571) Directs the Secretary concerned to provide travel and transportation allowances for the relocation of abused dependents of military personnel.

(Sec. 572) Revises the date of commencement of the payment of transitional compensation to the dependents of members separated from the armed forces for dependent abuse. Repeals a provision limiting the duration of such payment to the greater of the unserved portion of the member's period of obligated service or 12 months (thus making the duration of all such payments 36 months). Authorizes the Secretary concerned to make eligible for such transitional assistance dependents not otherwise eligible if such Secretary determines that extenuating circumstances justify such payments. Provides that either a voluntary or involuntary separation shall trigger such assistance.

(Sec. 575) Directs the Secretary to: (1) convene a working group to review and assess DOD progress in implementing recommendations of the Defense Task Force on Domestic Violence; and (2) ensure that necessary resources are provided to the DOD organization responsible for overseeing implementation of those recommendations.

(Sec. 577) Directs the Secretary to conduct a multidisciplinary, impartial review in the case of each fatality known or suspected to have resulted from domestic violence or child abuse from: (1) a member of the armed forces; (2) a current or former dependent of a member; or (3) a current or former intimate partner who has a child in common or has shared a common domicile with a member.

(Sec. 578) Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of: (1) Defense should adopt the strategic plan proposed by the Defense Task Force on Domestic Violence in its Third Year Report; and (2) each military department should establish and support a Victim Advocate Protocol and provide for nondisclosure to ensure confidentiality for victims who come forward to receive advocacy, support, information, and resources.

Title VI: Compensation and Other Personnel Benefits - Subtitle A: Pay and Allowances - (Sec. 601) Waives any FY 2004 pay increases tied to increases in the General Schedule of Compensation for Government employees. Increases, effective January 1, 2004, the rates of basic pay for military personnel. Increases by two percent, on the same effective date, the rates of compensation for members of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Public Health Service.

(Sec. 602) Provides for the computation of the basic pay rate for commissioned officers with prior enlisted or warrant officer service.

(Sec. 603) Authorizes the Secretary to provide to a member assigned to duty in a high-cost duty location or under other unique and unusual circumstances, but not entitled to the meals portion of the per diem allowance in connection with such duty, to: (1) meals at no cost; (2) a basic allowance for subsistence at the standard rate; and (3) a supplemental subsistence allowance at a rate higher than the basic allowance for subsistence. Makes eligible for such meals or allowance members assigned to qualifying duty after September 11, 2001.

Subtitle B: Bonuses and Special and Incentive Pays - (Sec. 611) Extends through 2004 specified authorities currently scheduled to expire at the end of 2003 with respect to certain special pay and bonus programs within the regular and reserve armed forces.

(Sec. 615) Provides for the computation of hazardous duty incentive pay for demolition duty and parachute jumping in military free fall operations for reserve personnel entitled to compensation for inactive-duty training.

(Sec. 616) Makes reserve personnel on inactive duty eligible for hostile fire and imminent danger pay for periods during which such member: (1) was subject to hostile fire or explosion of hostile mines; (2) was on duty in an area of imminent danger; (3) was killed, injured, or wounded in hostile action; or (4) was on duty in a foreign area in which the member was subject to the threat of harm or imminent danger due to civil insurrection, civil war, terrorism, or wartime conditions. Continues such eligibility during any period of required hospitalization.

(Sec. 617) Makes officers (currently, only enlisted personnel) eligible for: (1) special pay or a bonus for extending overseas tours of duty; and (2) a rest and recuperative absence in lieu of such pay or bonus.

(Sec. 618) Makes appointed warrant officers eligible for an accession bonus for new officers serving in critical skills positions.

(Sec. 619) Entitles to incentive pay of $5 per day a member who performs duty on the ground in Antarctica or on an Arctic icepack.

(Sec. 620) Authorizes the Secretary of a military department to pay a special pay of $150 monthly to a member entitled to basic pay or a reserve member performing inactive duty training who is assigned to duty as a member of a Weapons of Mass Destruction Civil Support Team.

(Sec. 621) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to pay an incentive bonus of up to $4,000 to a member in pay grade E-6 who agrees to convert to, and serve for at least two years in, a critically short military occupational specialty. Requires a pro rata bonus repayment for any obligated period not successfully served. Terminates such authority on December 31, 2004.

(Sec. 622) Increases as of October 1, 2003, the rates of imminent danger pay and the family separation allowance for members serving in Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom.

(Sec. 623) Makes eligible for hostile fire and imminent danger pay reserve personnel who were on duty as first responders, or assigned to accompany or protect first responders, to a terrorist attack on the United States.

Subtitle C: Travel and Transportation Allowances - (Sec. 631) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to allow a member making a permanent change of station to arrange for the private shipment of a motor vehicle in lieu of motor vehicle transportation at the expense of the United States.

(Sec. 632) Authorizes the payment or reimbursement of student baggage storage costs for dependent children accompanying members assigned to a permanent change of station overseas at any time in the same fiscal year of such change in station, as selected by the member.

(Sec. 633) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to reimburse certain reserve and retired personnel called or ordered to active duty for a period of 30 days or more for lodging expenses incurred at the member's duty location while the member is in an authorized leave status. Makes such reimbursement applicable with respect to personnel so called or ordered after September 11, 2001.

Subtitle D: Retired Pay and Survivors Benefits - (Sec. 641) Makes the Department of Defense Military Retirement Fund the source of payments of special compensation for certain service-disabled military retirees. (Currently, such source is general funds available to the Secretary concerned for pay and allowances within that military department.) Requires the Secretary to: (1) determine the amount of Treasury contributions to be made to such Fund due to the increased payments for such retirees; and (2) adjust the Fund's actuarial valuation in light of such increased payments.

Subtitle E: Commissary and Nonappropriated Fund Instrumentality Benefits - (Sec. 651) Authorizes the use of military commissary stores on the same basis as for members on active duty for members of the Selected Reserve, members of the Ready Reserve not in the Selected Reserve, and reserve retirees under the age of 60, as well as their dependents. Repeals provisions limiting commissary access to 24 days per year for Ready Reserve personnel with 50 or more retirement-creditable points and persons qualified for military retired pay but for being under 60 years of age.

(Sec. 652) Directs the Secretary to operate as separate DOD systems a defense commissary system and an exchange stores system.

(Sec. 653) Prohibits: (1) private persons from performing functions related to the procurement of products to be sold in, or the overall management of, a commissary system or store; and (2) any change to private operation of a commissary store function from taking effect until the Secretary notifies Congress of such change and 90 days has elapsed since such notification.

(Sec. 654) Requires (currently law authorizes) commissary store operating expenses to be paid from appropriated funds (as opposed to nonappropriated fund instrumentalities). Allows amounts appropriated to cover operating expenses of the Defense Commissary Agency and the defense commissary system to be supplemented by amounts received as reimbursement for support activities provided by commissary activities.

(Sec. 655) Amends the Defense Authorization Amendments and Base Closure and Realignment Act and the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 to make defense base closure account funds available to the Secretary, without appropriation and until expended, to acquire, construct and improve commissary stores and real property and facilities for nonappropriated fund instrumentalities. (Currently, the Secretary is authorized to use such funds in such aggregate amounts as provided in advance in appropriation Acts.)

(Sec. 656) Authorizes the Secretary to conduct a pilot program under which the stocking of shelves at three defense commissary stores operated by the Defense Commissary Agency shall be the sole responsibility of Agency employees or employees contracted by the Agency. Requires a program report from the Secretary to the defense committees.

Subtitle F: Other Matters - (Sec. 661) Repeals the requirement of prior congressional notification prior to the designation of critical military skills for purposes of eligibility for a retention bonus.

Title VII: Health Care Provisions - (Sec. 701) Authorizes the Secretary to determine separate Medicare-eligible retiree health care fund valuations and contributions for each of the participating military departments.

(Sec. 702) Transfers certain contractors and providers under the DOD pharmacy benefits program from membership on the Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee to membership on the Uniform Formulary Beneficiary Advisory Panel.

(Sec. 703) Makes permanent (currently, terminates on December 31, 2003) DOD authority to enter into personal services contracts for health care services to be performed at locations outside military medical treatment facilities.

(Sec. 704) Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop a plan for providing DOD health coverage information to members, former members, and dependents eligible for certain benefits, including benefits under TRICARE (a DOD managed health care plan); (2) implement such plan with respect to any health care contract entered into by DOD after May 31, 2003; and (3) report to the defense committees on such plan and a schedule for implementation.

(Sec. 705) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993 to direct the Secretary to establish a working group on the provision of military health care to persons who rely for such care at military installations selected for closure or realignment either under the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 or as a result of force posture changes.

(Sec. 706) Requires the Secretary to accelerate implementation of the plan required under the Floyd D. Spence National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2001 relating to chiropractic health care services and benefits, with a goal of fully implementing the plan by October 1, 2005.

(Sec. 707) Authorizes the provision of medical and dental screening for Selected Reserve personnel called or ordered to active duty in support of an operational mission or contingency operation during a national emergency or in time of war.

Title VIII: Acquisition Policy, Acquisition Management, and Related Matters - Subtitle A: Amendments to General Contracting Authorities, Procedures, and Limitations - (Sec. 801) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1994 to extend through FY 2008 DOD authority to carry out certain prototype projects.

(Sec. 802) Makes certain contractor-to-agency notification requirements with respect to cost contracts and cost-plus-a-fixed-fee contracts inapplicable to a prime contract with a contractor that maintains a purchasing system approved by the contracting officer for that contract.

(Sec. 803) Repeals the requirement that a procurement contractor include written assurances regarding the completeness, accuracy, and contractual sufficiency of technical data provided by the contractor.

(Sec. 804) Requires, unless otherwise specifically authorized, the use of competitive procedures for modifying the scope, period, or maximum value of a task or delivery order contract. Requires notification of any such modification through the Federal Register. Repeals provisions: (1) limiting the period of a task order contract to five years; (2) prohibiting a task order from increasing the scope, period, or maximum value of a task order contract; and (3) authorizing task order contract extensions in specified circumstances.

(Sec. 805) Authorizes the Secretary to enter into personal services contracts with individuals, regardless of their nationality, outside of the United States. Authorizes the Secretary to enter into such contracts in the United States if the personal services directly support the mission of a defense intelligence component, counter-intelligence organization, or special operations command.

(Sec. 806) Directs the Secretary to evaluate laws and regulations relating to the prompt payment of amounts due contractors under DOD contracts.

Subtitle B: United States Defense Industrial Base Provisions - Part I: Critical Items Identification and Domestic Production Capabilities Improvement Program - (Sec. 811) Directs the Secretary, in coordination with each department Secretary, to establish a program to assess the capabilities of the U.S. defense industrial base to produce military systems necessary to support national security requirements. Requires each department Secretary to designate a person responsible for assisting in carrying out the program with respect to that department (with specified duties). Requires the Secretary to collect certain data in support of the program, including contracts and their bids and proposals, and to ensure that collected information remains confidential. Directs the Secretary, every two years, to prepare an assessment of the data compiled and report such assessment to the defense committees.

(Sec. 812) Directs the Secretary to: (1) establish a process to identify essential and critical items and components with respect to each military system; (2) produce a list of such items, to be known as the military system breakout list; and (3) report annually to the defense committees on the implementation of such requirements.

(Sec. 813) Authorizes the Secretary, with respect to critical items having limited sources of production capability in the United States, to procure such items only if they are entirely produced in the United States, with an exception for an unusual and compelling urgency in the need for such item.

(Sec. 814) Establishes in the Treasury the Defense Industrial Base Capabilities Fund to establish capabilities within the United States to produce critical items that are currently available only from foreign contractors or a limited number of U.S. contractors. Authorizes appropriations. Requires the Secretary to report to Congress before obligating any Fund amounts.

Part II: Requirements Relating to Specific Items - (Sec. 821) Adds specified items, including aircraft and ground vehicle tires and tank track assemblies and components, to the list of items which may be procured only from a manufacturer that is part of the national technology and industrial base. Excludes Canadian persons or organizations from possible manufacturers under such base. Removes several exceptions under which the Secretary may waive such procurement requirement. Adds as a new exception the case where DOD's need for the item is of such unusual and compelling urgency that the United States would be seriously injured unless DOD is permitted to procure the item outside the United States.

(Sec. 822) Includes specialty metals that may be part of another item among those items that may only be procured by DOD if reprocessed, reused, or produced in the United States. Repeals a provision allowing the Secretary of a military department to determine that an item's U.S. availability is insufficient and that an exception may be made to the procurement requirement (thereby allowing only the Secretary to make such a determination). Requires the Secretary to notify Congress of each such determination. Prohibits the Secretary from delegating any authority under such requirements other than to the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics. Provides an exception for commercial items containing specialty metals if the Secretary determines that DOD's need for the item is of such unusual and compelling urgency that the United States would be seriously injured unless DOD is permitted to procure the item elsewhere. Prohibits the Secretary from exercising the exception with respect to commercial items containing specialty metals until 15 days after notifying Congress.

(Sec. 823) Directs the Secretary to identify foreign countries that, by law, policy, or regulation, restricted the provision or sale of military goods or services to the United States because of U.S. policy toward, or military operations in, Iraq since September 12, 2002. Prohibits the Secretary from procuring any items or components manufactured in any foreign country so identified. Authorizes a waiver for unusual and compelling urgency.

(Sec. 825) Amends the Strom Thurmond National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1999 to repeal the authority for limited foreign procurement of para-aramid fibers and yarns.

(Sec. 826) Directs the Secretary, for any procurement of a major defense acquisition program, to require that: (1) the contractor for the procurement use only machine tools entirely produced within the United States to carry out the contract; and (2) any subcontractor follow such requirements in the case of any contract of $5 million or greater.

(Sec. 827) Directs the Secretary to: (1) collect data to identify all contractors and subcontractors that use machine tools in carrying out any defense contract of $5 million or greater; and (2) establish a center to provide technical assistance to U.S. machine tool companies, and entities that use such tools, to seek guidance with respect to Government contracting regulations, including compliance procedures, and opportunities for contracting with DOD.

(Sec. 828) Prohibits the Secretary, when determining whether application of Buy American requirements are inconsistent with the public interest, from considering the provisions of any trade agreement between the United States and a foreign country.

(Sec. 829) Defines "substantially all," for purposes of the U.S.-produced articles, materials, and supplies requirement of the Buy American Act, as 65 percent.

Part III: General Provisions - (Sec. 831) Adds specified definitions with respect to DOD contracting for military systems necessary to support national security requirements.

Title IX: Department of Defense Organization and Management - (Sec. 901) Redesignates the position of Secretary of the Navy as Secretary of the Navy and Marine Corps.

(Sec. 902) Redesignates the National Imagery and Mapping Agency as the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. Includes geospatial intelligence within such Agency's missions. Makes conforming amendments necessitated by such redesignation under defense intelligence provisions as well as the National Security Act of 1947.

(Sec. 903) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a three-year pilot program to determine the feasibility and desirability of providing to non-U.S. Governmental entities specified space surveillance data support, including tracking services and data analysis. Requires a recipient to: (1) pay for such services; and (2) agree not to transfer any data or information received to any other entity without the Secretary's express approval. Prohibits services or information concerning or derived from U.S. intelligence assets or data from being provided under the pilot program.

(Sec. 905) Directs the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to report biennially to the defense committees on the results of a comprehensive examination of the national military strategy, including the risks associated with executing current missions. Requires each such report to first be submitted to the Secretary, who shall include assessments and comments before forwarding the reports to such committees.

(Sec. 906) Authorizes the Secretary to accept any (currently, only foreign) gifts or donations on behalf of the Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies.

(Sec. 907) Amends the Defense Economic Adjustment, Diversification, Conversion, and Stabilization Act of 1990 to make the Secretary the permanent Chairman of the Economic Adjustment Committee. (Currently, such chairmanship rotates between the Secretaries of Defense, Labor, and Commerce.)

(Sec. 908) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a two-year pilot program using an automated workforce management system to demonstrate improved efficiency in the performance of civilian personnel management. Directs the Secretary to submit to the defense committees an implementation plan 30 days in advance of carrying out the pilot program.

(Sec. 909) Includes within Federal provisions concerning the operation and control of the Pentagon Reservation and defense facilities in the National Capital Region the land and facilities at the Raven Rock Mountain Complex as well as other DOD land, locations, and physical facilities within 100 miles of the District of Columbia determined by the Secretary as necessary to meet DOD needs directly relating to the continuity of operations and government.

(Sec. 910) Prohibits, as of October 1, 2008, the number of defense acquisition and support personnel from exceeding 75 percent of the baseline number (the number of such personnel as of October 1, 2003). Provides for a phased reduction of five percent per year until the 2008 date.

(Sec. 911) Provides a required force structure for the Army, Navy, and Air Force.

Title X: General Provisions - Subtitle A: Financial Matters - (Sec. 1001) Authorizes the Secretary, in the national interest, to transfer up to $2.5 billion of the amounts made available to DOD in this Act between any such authorizations for that fiscal year. Requires congressional notification of each transfer.

(Sec. 1002) Adjusts amounts authorized to be appropriated in the Stump Act by the amount by which appropriations pursuant to such authorizations were increased or decreased by any supplemental appropriations for FY 2003 for defense activities or atomic energy activities of the Department of Energy.

(Sec. 1003) Authorizes the Secretary to transfer funds available for procurement of a major defense acquisition program for further RDT&E for that program. Limits such transfer authority to $20 million per program and $250 million per fiscal year for all programs.

(Sec. 1004) Authorizes DOD, and the Secretary of Transportation with respect to the Coast Guard when not operating as a service in the Navy, to enter into a one-year lease of real or personal property for a period that begins in one fiscal year and ends in the next.

(Sec. 1005) Authorizes a military installation to use all (currently, two-thirds) of the energy savings realized by such installation for specified installation activities and functions.

(Sec. 1006) Amends the Department of Defense Authorization Act, 1986 to repeal the requirement for a two-year budget cycle for DOD.

(Sec. 1007) Authorizes the Secretary to reimburse military and civilian DOD personnel on a flat-rate basis for cellular telephone use on a privately owned cellular phone when used on official Government business.

Subtitle B: Naval Vessels and Shipyards - (Sec. 1011) Repeals the requirement that the Secretary of the Navy take certain action, when the number of Navy combatant surface vessels is less than 116, to ensure that such number may be reached within 120 days.

(Sec. 1012) Authorizes the sale of material and equipment stripped from a naval vessel stricken from the Naval Vessel Register. Includes within authorized experimental purposes for such ships Navy sink exercises or target practice.

(Sec. 1013) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to transfer any vessel stricken from the Naval Vessel Register to any State, U.S. possession, or municipal corporation or political subdivision thereof for use as an artificial reef.

(Sec. 1014) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to establish a pilot program to guarantee loans for the: (1) construction in a U.S. shipyard of two qualified sealift ships; and (2) acquisition of facilities or equipment pertaining to the marine operations of those ships. Authorizes appropriations.

Subtitle C: Reports - (Sec. 1021) Repeals or revises various reporting requirements applicable to DOD under Federal armed forces provisions and prior national defense authorization and appropriations Acts.

(Sec. 1022) Directs the Secretary to submit to the defense committees a preliminary and final report on Operation Iraqi Freedom, including a discussion of accomplishments and shortcomings and casualty statistics.

(Sec. 1023) Directs the Secretary to report to: (1) Congress on DOD activities in post-conflict Iraq; and (2) the defense and appropriations committees on the development of mechanisms to better connect DOD space capabilities with the war fighter.

Subtitle D: Procurement of Defense Biomedical Countermeasures - (Sec. 1031) Directs the Secretary to carry out a program to accelerate the research, development, and procurement of biomedical countermeasures, including therapeutics and vaccines, for protection of military personnel from attack by one or more biological, chemical, radiological, or nuclear agents. Provides for expedited procurement authority under the program. Authorizes the Secretary to enter into personal services contracts to carry out program activities.

(Sec. 1032) Requires the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Homeland Security, to: (1) assess current and emerging threats of the use of biological, chemical, radiological, and nuclear agents and identify those agents that present a material risk of use against the armed forces; and (2) assess the potential consequences to the health of military personnel of the use of such agents and identify those agents for which countermeasures are necessary. Directs the Secretary, on an ongoing basis, to identify specific countermeasures appropriate for procurement for the DOD stockpile of biomedical countermeasures. Provides funding from funds authorized for transfer under this title.

(Sec. 1033) Authorizes the use on military personnel of a drug or device during a period of a military emergency, or significant potential for such emergency, involving a heightened risk to such personnel of attack by one or more biological, chemical, radiological, or nuclear agents. Authorizes the Secretary to extend such periods of emergency. Provides criteria for issuance of the authority to use such drugs or devices.

Subtitle E: Other Matters - (Sec. 1041) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a program to administer counterintelligence polygraph examinations to: (1) military and civilian personnel of DOD; (2) personnel of defense contractors; (3) a person assigned or detailed to DOD; or (4) a person applying for a position with the National Security Agency (NSA). Provides exceptions for certain intelligence agencies and functions. Requires the Secretary to carry out a continuing research program to support DOD polygraph activities.

(Sec. 1042) Prohibits the Secretary of a military department from carrying out a significant modification (greater than $1 million) of an aircraft, weapon, vessel, or other item of equipment that such Secretary plans to retire or otherwise dispose of within five years after the date on which such modification, if carried out, would be completed. Provides an exception for safety modifications. Authorizes the Secretary concerned to waive such prohibition in the national security interest, requiring notification thereof to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 1043) Defines "congressional defense committees" and "base closure law" for purposes of Federal armed forces provisions. Makes technical and conforming amendments as required by such definitions.

(Sec. 1044) Requires inclusion in the annual defense authorization request from the Secretary to Congress of the authority to carry out military construction projects. Repeals the requirement of a separate transmission of request for such projects.

(Sec. 1045) Makes technical and clerical amendments to Federal armed forces and military pay and allowances provisions, prior national defense authorization Acts, the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994, and the Armed Forces Retirement Home Act of 1991.

(Sec. 1046) Authorizes the NSA Director to provide living quarters to a student in the Student Educational Employment Program or similar program while the student is employed at the Agency laboratory.

(Sec. 1047) Authorizes the Secretary, during FY 2004 and 2005, to use funds made available to DOD for drug interdiction and counter-drug activities to provide assistance to the Government of Colombia to: (1) support a unified campaign against narcotics trafficking; (2) support a unified campaign against activities by designated terrorist organizations; and (3) take actions to protect human health and welfare in emergency circumstances, including undertaking rescue operations.

(Sec. 1048) Authorizes a joint task force of DOD that provides support to law enforcement agencies conducting counter-drug activities to also provide support to such agencies in conducting counter-terrorism activities.

(Sec. 1049) Amends Federal transportation law to allow an individual being investigated for eligibility for access to classified information or for Federal employment to request the chief driver licensing official of a State to provide driver information about the individual to any Federal department or agency authorized to investigate the individual to determine eligibility for such access or employment.

(Sec. 1050) Amends the National Security Agency Act of 1959 to authorize the NSA Director to exempt from public disclosure NSA operational files (files that document the means by which foreign intelligence or counterintelligence is collected through technical systems). Provides exceptions. Makes judicial review available, under specified procedures, whenever a person who has requested records under the Freedom of Information Act alleges that the NSA has improperly withheld such records under the operational files exemption. Requires the Directors of NSA and Central Intelligence, at least once every ten years, to review the exemptions in force at the time to determine whether any should be removed. Requires: (1) the Director of Central Intelligence to approve any determination to remove an exemption; and (2) the reviews to consider the historical value or other public interest of such files or portions thereof.

(Sec. 1051) Directs the Secretary to assist the United States Air and Trade Show Inc., for expenses of a study of the feasibility of establishing and operating a biennial U.S. international air trade show. Requires such organization to submit a report to the Secretary on study results. Provides assistance limits.

(Sec. 1052) Provides that an amendment or other revision to a DOD directive relating to access to military installations for conducting limited personal commercial solicitation shall not take effect until 90 days after the Secretary submits to Congress notice of the amendment or revision and the reasons therefor.

(Sec. 1053) Establishes the Commission on Nuclear Strategy of the United States to assess and make recommendations about current U.S. nuclear strategy as envisioned in the National Security Strategy of the United States and the Nuclear Posture Review, as well as possible alternative future strategies. Requires special attention to be given to how such strategy has advanced or adversely affected relations with Russia. Requires the Commission to include in its report recommendations for any continuities or changes in nuclear strategy to enhance U.S. national security. Requires reports from: (1) the Commission to the Secretary and the defense committees on its findings and conclusions; (2) the Secretary to Congress on such findings and implementation thereof. Terminates the Commission 60 days after its report.

(Sec. 1054) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1994 to extend through FY 2008 the Counterproliferation Program Review Committee.

(Sec. 1055) Authorizes the Secretary, upon request of the Secretary of Homeland Security, to assign military personnel to assist: (1) the Bureau of Border Security in preventing the entry of terrorists, drug traffickers, and illegal aliens into the United States; and (2) the U.S. Customs Service in the inspection of cargo, vehicles, and aircraft at U.S. points of entry to prevent the entry of weapons of mass destruction, prohibited narcotics or drugs, or other terrorist or drug trafficking items. Requires: (1) such Secretaries to establish a training program for military personnel performing such services; and (2) a civilian law enforcement officer from the agency concerned to accompany each member performing such services. Authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish ongoing joint task forces to respond to threats to national security posed by the entry into the United States of terrorists, drug traffickers, or illegal aliens. Terminates the assignment authority at the end of FY 2005.

(Sec. 1056) Requires annual reports from the President to Congress concerning any strategic nuclear warheads dismantled pursuant to the Treaty Between the United States of America and the Russian Federation on Strategic Offensive Reduction.

(Sec. 1057) Authorizes the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to procure the services of military aircraft and appropriate personnel of Air Force and Air National Guard Modular Airborne Fire Fighting Systems units in California, Colorado, North Carolina, and Wyoming to fight wildfires. Terminates such authority on December 31, 2005. Requires such Secretaries to report to Congress on such program.

(Sec. 1058) Directs the Secretary to commission a study of the feasibility of using small businesses, minority-owned businesses, and women-owned businesses in U.S. efforts to rebuild Iraq.

(Sec. 1059) Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary should maintain the functions and missions of the Army Peacekeeping Institute at the Army War College in Carlisle, Pennsylvania, or within a joint entity of DOD to ensure that members continue to study the strategic challenges and uses of peacekeeping missions.

(Sec. 1060) Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense committees assessing the effects of specified statutory limitations on the granting of security clearances for DOD and defense contractor personnel.

Title XI: Department of Defense Civilian Personnel - Subtitle A: Department of Defense Civilian Personnel Generally - (Sec. 1101) Revises the maximum overtime pay rate for Federal employees whose basic pay exceeds the minimum rate of basic pay for GS-10 employees.

(Sec. 1102) Makes eligible for military leave Federal civilian employees who perform full-time military service as a result of a call or order to active duty in support of a contingency operation.

(Sec. 1103) Applies to the pay of both Federal prevailing rate employees and General Schedule rate employees an identical standard for determination of the differential for any hardship or hazard related to asbestos by applying occupational safety and health standards consistent with the permissible exposure limit under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970.

(Sec. 1104) Increases from $6,000 to $10,000 the calendar year limit on student loan amounts authorized to be paid by the head of a Federal agency in order to recruit or retain highly qualified personnel.

(Sec. 1105) Authorizes Cabinet Secretaries, Secretaries of military departments, and heads of executive agencies to be paid on a bi-weekly (currently, monthly) basis.

(Sec. 1106) Excludes Senior Executive Service positions, including those within the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration, from current Federal comparability pay requirements.

Revises Federal provisions establishing pay rates for the Senior Executive Service. Requires each senior executive to be paid based on individual performance, contribution to the agency's performance, or both, as determined under a rigorous performance management system. Increases to level III (currently, level IV) of the Executive Schedule the highest rate of pay for a senior executive, or to level II for any agency certified as having a performance appraisal system which makes meaningful distinctions based or relative performance. Includes certain senior executives within current Federal post-employment restrictions. Requires the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to promulgate regulations requiring that each executive agency notify any employee subject to Federal post-employment restrictions.

(Sec. 1107) Prohibits a Federal pay-for-performance system from being initiated unless it incorporates specified elements, including a fair, credible, and transparent employee performance appraisal system and a link between elements of the pay-for-performance system, the performance appraisal system, and that agency's strategic plan.

(Sec. 1108) Prohibits a Federal agency or other employing entity which provides a flexible spending account option for its employees from imposing a fee to defray administrative costs associated therewith. Requires OPM to report to specified congressional committees on the Federal cost of the option program for FY 2003, as well as projected administrative costs over the next five fiscal years. Requires reports from entities employing such option to the OMB describing employment tax savings achieved, minus administrative fees paid.

(Sec. 1109) Prohibits a Federal employee or individual who was employed in the DOD's Office of Inspector General and transferred to a Special Court sponsored by the United Nations from being subject, while holding the latter position, to Federal prohibitions on engaging in certain political activities.

(Sec. 1110) Requires each agency to conduct annual employee surveys to assess: (1) leadership and management practices that contribute to agency performance; and (2) employee satisfaction. Requires survey results to be made publicly available and posted on the agency website.

(Sec. 1111) Establishes the Human Capital Performance Fund for agency payments to individual employees based on exceptional performance contributing to the achievement of the agency mission. Prohibits any payment from exceeding ten percent of the employee's rate of basic pay. Requires each agency to submit to OPM a plan for participation in the Fund which shall include, among other things, a fair, credible, and transparent employee performance appraisal system as well as a link between a pay-for-performance system, the performance appraisal system, and the agency's strategic plan. Requires the Chief Human Capital Officers Council to include in its annual report to Congress an evaluation of the formulation and implementation of agency performance management systems. Authorizes appropriations.

Subtitle B: Department of Defense National Security Personnel System - (Sec. 1121) Authorizes the Secretary, in regulations prescribed jointly with the OPM Director, to establish and periodically adjust a human resources management system for some or all of the organizational or functional units of DOD. Sets forth system requirements.

Prohibits the total amount of basic pay and other awards, allowances, etc. received by certain DOD senior executive or equivalent employees from exceeding the total compensation payable to the Vice President. Sets forth requirements to ensure the participation of employee representatives in the planning, development, and implementation of any management system. Excludes the National Guard Bureau and the Army and Air National Guard from such collective bargaining requirements and procedures.

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) DOD employees are entitled to fair treatment in any appeals they bring in decisions relating to their employment; and (2) the Secretary should ensure that such employees are afforded the protections of due process and that regulations affecting such employment should be issued only after consultation with the Merit Systems Protection Board.

Authorizes the Secretary to establish a program under which employees may be eligible for early retirement, offered incentive pay to separate from service voluntarily, or both. Entitles to early retirement any employee who is at least 50 years of age and has completed 20 years of service, or any employee who has completed 25 years of service. Provides separation incentive pay limits. Prohibits an employee receiving separation pay from being reemployed by DOD within 12 months, with exceptions on a case-by-case basis, or from being reemployed by the Federal Government within five years (requiring forfeiture of the entire separation incentive amount under the latter reemployment).

Authorizes the use of DOD funds to: (1) contract with individuals for services to be performed outside the United States in support of DOD programs and activities; (2) carry out the national security mission of DOD (including, again, the use of personal services contracts); and (3) procure the services of experts and consultants.

Authorizes the Secretary to carry out a program to attract highly qualified experts in needed occupations within DOD. Limits to five years the term of appointment under such program, with limitations on additional payments to such employees.

Authorizes the Secretary to appoint older Americans (at least 55 years of age) to positions in the excepted service for a period not to exceed two years, allowing for an extension of up to two additional years if the individual possesses unique knowledge or abilities not otherwise available to DOD.

Authorizes the Secretary to pay special allowances and benefits to certain DOD civilians employed outside the United States.

Title XII: Matters Relating to Other Nations - (Sec. 1201) Authorizes the Secretary to provide administrative services and support for the performance of duties by a liaison officer of any other nation (currently, only of nations involved in a coalition with the United States). Removes the requirement that such an officer be only temporarily employed with a combatant or operational command of the United States to receive such services and support. Authorizes the provision of travel, subsistence, and other expenses for such officers.

(Sec. 1202) Authorizes the Secretary to expend DOD O&M funds to present awards and mementos to recognize superior noncombat achievements or performance by members of friendly forces or foreign nationals that significantly enhance or support U.S. national security strategy.

(Sec. 1203) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1995 to authorize the Secretary to waive the costs of charges for attendance at the George C. Marshall European Center for Security Studies for individuals from states located in Europe or the territory of the former Soviet Union (currently, only for individuals from partner states of the North Atlantic Council or the Partnership for Peace).

(Sec. 1204) Directs the Secretary to maintain a list of any goods or technology that, if obtained by a potential adversary, could undermine the military superiority or qualitative military advantage of the United States over potential adversaries. Requires the list to be updated at least every two months.

(Sec. 1205) Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense and foreign relations committees on the acquisition by Iraq of: (1) weapons of mass destruction and associated delivery systems; and (2) advanced conventional weapons.

(Sec. 1206) Authorizes a Federal disbursing official, under specified conditions, to offer check cashing and other monetary exchange transactions for a member of the military forces of an allied or coalition nation who is participating with U.S. forces in a joint operation, joint exercise, or humanitarian or peacekeeping mission.

(Sec. 1207) Includes T-2 Buckeye and T-37 Tweet aircraft under current authority to transfer certain aircraft to a foreign country for flight operations, after any required maintenance and repair.

(Sec. 1208) Prohibits any DOD funds from being used to support or maintain more than 500 U.S. military personnel on duty at any one time in the Republic of Colombia. Excludes certain personnel from such limitation. Authorizes the waiver of such prohibition for national security purposes (requiring notification of the defense and appropriations committees within 15 days after exercising the waiver).
